title: Quiz 3: Gender, Rights & Harmful Practices
topicName: Unit One: Introduction to Reproductive Health
description: Test your understanding of gender concepts, harmful cultural practices (FGM, etc.), and types of gender-based violence.

questions.question: What is the fundamental difference between 'Gender' and 'Sex'?

options.text: Gender refers to social/cultural attributes; Sex refers to biological characteristics
Gender is biological; Sex refers to social/cultural roles
Gender is fixed; Sex changes over time

questions.explanation: Sex refers to biological characteristics (male/female), while Gender refers to economic, social, or cultural attributes constructed by society.
questions.hint: One is biological, the other is social.

questions.question: Review the definition below. Which type of FGM is described?

richContent.content: Procedure: Removal of the clitoris, labia minora, and part of the labia majora. The vulva sides are stitched together leaving a small opening.

questions.explanation: Infibulation is the most severe form, involving cutting and pinning/stitching the vulva to leave only a small opening.
questions.hint: This type involves narrowing the vaginal opening.

questions.question: What are the potential negative consequences of Wife Inheritance? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: While traditionally intended for lineage, wife inheritance now facilitates the spread of HIV/AIDS and often leads to the economic abuse of widows.

questions.question: Match the form of abuse with its specific description:

pairs.right: Denial of land ownership or income control

questions.explanation: Physical=Bodily harm; Economic=Financial control; Sexual=Unwanted sexual contact; Psychological=Mental/Emotional harm.
questions.hint: Match the action to the category.

questions.question: According to the World Bank, violence against women causes more death and disability in women aged 15-44 than ___BLANK___, malaria, traffic accidents, and war combined.
questions.explanation: Gender-based violence is a leading cause of morbidity/mortality, exceeding cancer in this age group.

questions.question: Rape is primarily a crime motivated by sexual desire and seductiveness.
questions.explanation: Rape rarely has anything to do with sex or seductiveness; it has everything to do with power, coercion, and domination.
questions.hint: Is it about sex or power?

questions.question: Rank the following forms of FGM from least extensive tissue removal to most extensive (based on definitions):
questions.explanation: Circumcision involves the hood; Excision involves clitoris/minora; Infibulation involves extensive cutting and stitching.
questions.hint: Start with the procedure that removes the least tissue.

questions.question: What is the term for 'a systematic pattern of behaviour in a relationship used to gain or maintain control over another'?
questions.explanation: Abuse is defined as a systematic pattern of behavior to gain/maintain control (as opposed to violence which is the act of force).
questions.hint: It can be physical, emotional, or sexual.

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of gender inequalities observed in communities? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Inequality in food distribution (nutritional taboos for girls)
Access to medical care (delayed for girls)

questions.explanation: Gender inequalities manifest in education, nutrition (food), and healthcare access, often disadvantaging the girl child.
questions.hint: Think about traditional preferences for male children.

questions.question: Which form of aggression is performed solely to achieve a goal (like a robbery) without necessarily being angry?
questions.explanation: Instrumental aggression is used as an instrument to achieve a goal, unlike hostile aggression which is driven by anger.
questions.hint: It is used as an 'instrument' or tool.
